awd_titl_txt: EFRI NewLAW: Engineering Multiscale Photonic Systems with Broken Time-Reversal Invariance
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Most physical laws hold true whether time is moving forward or backward ? that is, they are time symmetric. However, violation of time-reversal symmetry underlies many of today?s most important devices ? from nanoscale diodes of integrated electronics to the macroscale isolators and circulators of fiber optical networks. To enable next- generation applications like integrated nano- and micro-photonic circuits, it is crucial to manipulate time-reversal symmetry in optics. This project will investigate time and space symmetries in multi-length-scale photonic systems and explore the exciting applications and technologies that emerge when such symmetries are violated. Our multi-disciplinary team of scientists from five institutions will employ complementary strategies to violate time-reversal symmetry and induce non-reciprocal light transport in nano-, micro-, and macro-scale photonic systems. Our discoveries have the potential to enable a host of new technologies that will ultimately contribute to critical national needs in public health, information processing, computation, and communications. Team members will collaborate with visual and performing artists and develop educational modules for elementary and secondary school students. Each member will involve undergraduate and graduate students from their own and other institutions in their research through cutting-edge online workshops and courses. A key goal is to broaden outreach to underrepresented groups from high schools, community colleges, and minority- serving institutions and create new educational and community resources to advance STEM education.

Technical description: In this EFRI NewLAW project, our multi-disciplinary team will employ a holistic approach to explore the emerging frontier of non-reciprocity and time-reversal symmetry breaking in photonic systems ranging from nanoscale plasmonic structures and dielectric micro- resonators to large scale integrated acousto-optic platforms. The research goals of the project will be achieved by synergistic efforts including theoretical investigation, numerical modeling, top-down and bottom-up materials synthesis, and device fabrication and characterization. Using complementary Hermitian and non-Hermitian approaches, the team aims to realize asymmetric and non-reciprocal optical transport in nanoscale, microscale, and macroscale systems. In Hermitian systems, acoustic and optical waves will be coupled in an integrated device in order to experimentally demonstrate how effective photon magnetic fields can influence photon transport. Utilizing the intrinsic phase properties of the acoustic wave, an effective gauge field can be generated for the optical waves, resulting in intriguing magnetic effects. This system will enable investigation of such fascinating effects as the optical analog of Lorentz forces and quantum Hall effect. Moreover, it will provide a new nonreciprocal platform based on a multi-physics, dynamically modulated system. Topologically protected photon edge state and one-way light transport will be demonstrated in large-scale photonic lattices. In non-Hermitian systems, judiciously positioned gain and loss will be investigated to develop technologies that can enable nano and microscale non-reciprocal components and circuits. In particular, the utilization of antilinear symmetries and exceptional points will provide new strategies to compensate or mitigate losses in many physical systems to enable unconventional devices, such as chiral lasers, circulators, unity-efficiency polarizers and on-chip chiral-symmetric optical power limiters. This project will build the theoretical and experimental foundation for new non-reciprocal photonic materials and devices of multiple length-scales, enabling next generation technologies to address critical national needs in information processing and communications.

por.por_cntn:
This project involves a multidisciplinary research team with diverse expertise collaborating to develop new systems and techniques for studying non-reciprocity and time-reversal symmetry breaking in photonic systems. The team combines expertise in modeling and design, material synthesis, and fabrication of micro- and nano-structures, taking a holistic approach to explore this emerging field. Various materials and devices in different length scales, including non-Hermitian metasurfaces and metamaterials, photonic resonators with anti-linear symmetries, and hybrid acoustic/photonic devices, were designed and fabricated. The aim was to uncover and understand the unique properties emerging when symmetries of the physical systems, such as time-reversal symmetry, were broken.

In photonics, breaking time-reversal symmetry can be utilized to create optical components and systems with unique properties, such as nonreciprocal devices (e.g., isolators and circulators) that enable unidirectional light propagation and novel types of waveguiding and lasing. In certain systems, such as those that involve magnetic fields or nonreciprocal components, time-reversal symmetry can be broken, leading to a range of interesting and useful effects. Using the broken time-reversal symmetry can also lead to new non-Hermitian photonics systems possessing topological insulator features that can guide light along the edge state, with insensitivity to disorder and backscattering. On the fundamental level, the team investigated the underlying complex mathematical structures reflected in the topological properties of non-Hermitian spectral singularities, known as exceptional points (EPs), aiming to unravel novel transport phenomena; on the technological level, the effort focused on the realization of novel devices with unprecedented functionalities. For example, the Floquet scattering theory of driven photonic systems was studied to develop novel design schemes for efficient non-reciprocal devices.  The notion of non-Hermitian topological waveguides was developed to construct novel power switches that are robust against fabrication imperfections and become (almost) completely reflective for high incident power radiation. At the same time, these power switches demonstrated (almost) complete transmittivity for low power incident radiation.  A new concept of Floquet engineering scattering theory based on time-independent effective Hamiltonians that describe periodically modulated systems was developed and studied. This scheme has been utilized for the realization of various non-reciprocal components like isolators and circulators, as well as for developing a new concept of dynamically modulated perfect absorbers. The analysis of transport characteristics of classical wave systems in the system-parameter domain where exceptional point (EP) degeneracy is formed laid the theoretical foundation for the experimental groups to implement EP-enhanced sensing, which has been confirmed and demonstrated in many other physical systems beyond photonics.  

Moreover, the theoretical groups also coordinated with the experimental groups to develop analytical and numerical methods to model acoustic-optical systems. The analytical method exploits the coupled mode theory, a phenomenological method based on estimated parameters, such as the coupling strength and the non-reciprocal phase. An integrated acousto-optic device platform was designed and demonstrated experimentally to achieve efficient Brillouin scattering for non-reciprocal photonic devices and microwave photonics applications. An ultra-efficient, silicon-based nanophotonic cavity acousto-optic modulator on the AlN-on-SOI platform was designed and demonstrated. It showed that large-scale, complex-valued matrix-vector multiplications on synthetic frequency lattices can be performed using this device. By harnessing the resonantly enhanced strong electro-optomechanical coupling, a single such modulator achieved full-range phase-coherent frequency conversions across the entire synthetic lattice, which could be used to constitute a fully connected linear computing layer. This study will open up new avenues for the experimental realizations of frequency-domain integrated optical computing systems, simultaneously featuring very large-scale data processing and small device footprints.

The research discoveries from this project have laid the foundation to develop new, non-reciprocal photonic materials and devices with length scales ranging from nanometers to millimeters for a broad range of applications, from sensing to information processing and communication. This grant has supported (partially or in total) over thirty papers in peer-reviewed journals. In addition to publishing their research discoveries in scientific journals, the PIs have actively disseminated their research discoveries and results in various conferences, workshops, and department colloquia.

The project also offered education and research opportunities for students at different levels. For example, undergraduate students have worked directly with graduate students in the PIs’ research groups. They have opportunities to either carry out analytical and numerical simulations or get hands-on experiences in device fabrication, depending on the nature of the PIs’ research. Through this project, the PIs have supported multiple graduate students and postdocs to conduct the proposed research. Through these interactions, both students and postdocs are engaged in research discussions, which enrich their research experiences. In addition to working in the lab for comprehensive training in device design and fabrication, the students and postdocs also attended professional conferences, such as the Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics (CLEO) and SPIE Photonics West, where they had the opportunity to interact with the research community in both academia and industry.
